#Text=Make Graphene
#Text=Graphene is the wonder material of the century .
#Text=Considering its relative strength compared to its weight , it is harder than steel and diamonds and also the best conductor of heat and electricity .
#Text=And it 's only 1 atom thick !
#Text=You can make your own graphene at home , but be aware that it is more on the experimental level — you wo n’t be able to produce quantities large enough to do anything with .
#Text=If during your experiment you find a cost-effective way to mass-produce the graphene , you could become rich and famous !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Using the Sticky Tape Method
#Text=Deposit a thick layer of graphite onto a piece of paper with a lead pencil .
#Text=Start out by drawing just a small polka dot or a line to get a feeling for the process .
#Text=Go over the shape 2 or 3 times to get a nice , thick layer .
#Text=Alternatively , you can purchase powdered graphite at your local department or home improvement store for about $ 10.00 for .
#Text=Use tweezers to place a small amount of the powder onto the piece of paper .
#Text=A pinch would be too much .
#Text=Cut a 2 inch ( 5.1 cm ) piece of tape and place it on the graphite .
#Text=Position the tape over the graphite so that the graphite will be about three-quarters of the way down the tape .
#Text=Press the tape down on the graphite and then gently peel it off of the piece of paper .
#Text=Fold the piece of tape in half and then peel it apart .
#Text=Grasp the tape on the edges and only fold it enough to cover the graphite .
#Text=If you fold it completely in half , it will be difficult to open it up and pull it apart again .
#Text=Here , you are splitting the layers of graphite and separating the carbon atoms — which is necessary to get graphene .
#Text=Alternatively , you may place a fresh piece of tape on top of the original piece and then peel it off .
#Text=Repeat the process of folding and peeling about 20 times .
#Text=Each time you peel the tape off , the graphite layers get thinner and thinner .
#Text=After about 20 times of peeling , you should end up with a layer of graphite that is only 1 atom thick .
#Text=This is graphene .
#Text=If you are using fresh pieces of tape , rather than folding , place the third piece of tape on top of the second piece ; the fourth piece of tape on top of the third , and so on .
#Text=Use a microscope to tell how many layers of graphite you have .
#Text=Place the piece of tape , sticky side down , on a microscope slide .
#Text=View the slide between 100x and 400x magnification .
#Text=If you used the same piece of tape folded on top of itself multiple times , you will notice that some spots will be darker and some will be lighter .
#Text=The lighter spots are the thinnest layers and the lightest spot is the graphene .
#Text=If you used fresh pieces of tape to peel layers each time , use your final piece of tape ( about the 20th piece ) to place under the microscope .
#Text=Using a Kitchen Blender
#Text=Put of graphite powder into a kitchen blender .
#Text=If you do n’t have graphite powder , you can make some by pulverizing a few pencil leads in a pulverizer or grinder .
#Text=Use a high-power kitchen blender of at least 400 watts to get the best results .
#Text=Be aware that you can no longer use this blender to make food or drinks after using it with graphite .
#Text=Pour of liquid dish soap into the blender .
#Text=The detergent acts as a surfactant which works to suspend the graphene particles in the mixture .
#Text=It also prevents the particles from clumping together .
#Text=The brand of dish soap you use does n’t matter , however , the amount you add to the mixture does .
#Text=The exact amount of dish soap that ’s needed depends on the properties of the graphite powder and whether there are any other contaminants in the sample .
#Text=Unfortunately , these factors cannot be known without the use of advanced lab equipment .
#Text=Experiment with adding amounts within the range to start , and then do additional experiments by adding either more or less soap .
#Text=Add of water and blend on high for 10-30 minutes .
#Text=As the graphite is blended , it will create a black liquid that may be frothy .
#Text=Eventually you will begin to notice tiny flakes forming on the surface of the liquid and on the side of the blender .
#Text=Without lab equipment , it is difficult to distinguish between actual flakes of graphene and small flakes of graphite .
#Text=In general , if the graphene particles are too big ( still graphite ) , they will sink to the bottom of the blender ; if they are smaller , they will float to the top .
#Text=Particles that are suspended mid-water are nanoparticles , and are definitely graphene .
#Text=Pour the mixture into a glass jar and allow it to sit for 2-3 days .
#Text=In a lab , they centrifuge the mixture to separate the graphene from the liquid .
#Text=Since it is unlikely that you have access to a centrifuge , simply pour the liquid mixture into a glass jar and let it sit for a few days .
#Text=This resting period will allow the graphene to separate from the larger particles of graphite .
#Text=Things You ’ll Need
#Text=Lead pencil
#Text=Powdered graphite
#Text=Tape
#Text=Kitchen blender
#Text=Dishwashing liquid
#Text=Tips
#Text=Since making graphene at home is largely experimental , the exact measurements for creating it in a blender is unknown .
#Text=The measurements listed here are based off of one group of researcher ’s findings .
#Text=Making graphene at home is mostly just a proof-of-concept .
#Text=It is unlikely that you will be able to make enough high-quality graphene to be of any productive use .
#Text=But it ’s a fun experiment !
#Text=Quick Summary
